div.l: The myller goth a yeyne no word he seyde
But doth his note ⁊and wᵗith churles pleyde
Till that hur corn was feyre y grounde
And when the mele is sacked rounde
This Iohn goth out ⁊and fyndeth his hors a weye
And bi gan to crye a rout ⁊and welaweye
Oure hors is lost Aleyne for cristes bones
Step vp thi feet come of mon at ones
Alas oure wardeyne hath his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyne al for yat the mele ⁊and the corn̄
Al was out of his mynde his husbondrye
What whiche wey is he gon he can crye
¶ The wyf cam lepyng out at a renne
Sheo seyde alas he goth into the fenne
Wᵗith wylde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthonk come on his hed that tyed him so
And he that bet shulde haue knyt the reyne
¶ Alas ꝙquod Iohn Aleyne for cristes peyne
Ley doıı̄un thi swerd ⁊and I wol myn also
I am as swift god wot as is a ro
Bi godes herte he shal not skape vs bathe
Whi hadde thou not put hym in the lathe
Ille hayl Aleyne bi god thou art a fonne
¶ This sely clerkes haue ful faste y ronne
Toward the fenne bothe Aleyne ⁊and eke Iohn
And when the myller say that thei were gon
He half a busshel of hure corn̄ hath take
And bad his wyf knede hit in a cake
And seyde I trowe the clerkes were a ferd
Yet can a myller make a clerkes berd
For al hur͗e art yet let hem go hur wey
Lo where thei go yet let the children pley
